Documents/Programming/Projects/SSYAlert/Ex-Project-Categories/NS(Attributed)String+Geometrics.h

00001 /*
00002  
00003  * SUMMARY
00004  
00005  The methods in these @interfaces are typically used to dynamically size
00006  an NSTextView or NSTextField to fit their strings.  They return the
00007  ^used^ size, width or height of the given string/attributes, constrained
00008  by the maximum dimensions passed in the 'width' and 'height' arguments. 
00009  
00010  * RENDERING IN NSTextView VS. NSTextField
00011  
00012  Text rendered in a multiline line-wrapped NSTextField leaves much more
00013  space between lines than text rendered in an NSTextView.  The total points
00014  per line is typically 10-20% higher.
00015  
00016  Because most apps use NSTextView to render multiline text, using a 
00017  line-wrapped NSTextField looks funny, and obviously it wastes useful
00018  screen area.  But there are more subtle disadavantages if you wish to 
00019  estimate the size of the rendered text, typically done in 
00020  order to size the view.
00021  
00022  First of all, you cannot get a perfect estimate of the height.
00023  Although using the proper typesetterBehavior in the NSLayoutManager
00024  providing the estimate fixes the severe 10-20% underestimation which
00025  you'd get from using the default NSTypesetterLatestBehavior,
00026  it still usually gives results that are a little inaccurate.
00027  The error depends on the font and the size.
00028  For Arial and Helvetica, the calculated height is usually underestimated
00029  by the measure of one glyph descender; i.e. the measurement extends
00030  only to the baseline of the last line.
00031  For Lucida Grande smaller-sized fonts (9-10 pt), and for most sizes of
00032  Goudy Old Style, the calculated height is overestimated, by about one line.
00033  For Stencil, the calculated height is accurate.
00034  For Zapfino, the calculated height is usually underrestimated by 1-3 pixels.
00035  These are the only fonts that I looked at the results for.
00036  
00037  Finally, although the typesetterBehavior seems to be, at this time,
00038  equal to NSTypesetterBehavior_10_2_WithCompatibility, I suppose that
00039  this could change in the future.  This will change the vertical
00040  size of the rendered text.
00041  
00042  For these reasons, using a wrapped NSTextField to render multiline text is
00043  therefore discouraged in favor of using an NSTextView.
00044  
00045  * THE GLOBAL VARIABLE gNSStringGeometricsTypesetterBehavior
00046  
00047  The estimate of line spacing is controlled by the NSTypesetterBehavior
00048  setting in NSLayoutManager used in these methods.  Therefore, you must
00049  specify the NSTypsetterBehavior you desire when using one of these methods
00050  to get a measurement.
00051  
00052  Rather than providing a 'typsetterBehavior' argument in each of the methods in
00053  this category, which would make them really messy just to support a
00054  discouraged usage, a global variable, gNSStringGeometricsTypesetterBehavior, is
00055  initialized with the value NSTypesetterLatestBehavior.  This value is 
00056  appropriate to estimating height of text to be rendered in an NSTextView.
00057  This is also the default behavior in NSLayoutManager.
00058  
00059  Therefore, if you want to get measurements for text to be rendered in an
00060  NSTextView, these methods will "just work".
00061  
00062  Also, if you want to get the dimensions for text which will render in a
00063  single line, even in NSTextField, these methods will "just work".
00064  
00065  However, if you want to get dimensions of a string as rendered in the
00066  discouraged NSTextField with line wrapping, set the global variable
00067  gNSStringGeometricsTypesetterBehavior to 
00068  NSTypesetterBehavior_10_2_WithCompatibility before invoking these methods.
00069  Invoking any of these methods will automatically set it back to the
00070  default value of NSTypesetterLatestBehavior.
00071  
00072  * ARGUMENTS width and height
00073  
00074  In the sizeFor... methods, pass either a width or height which is known to 
00075  be larger than the width or height that is required.  Usually, one of these
00076  should be the "unlimited" value of FLT_MAX.
00077  If text will be drawn on one line, you may pass FLT_MAX for width.
00078  
00079  * ARGUMENT attributes, NSAttributedString attributes
00080  
00081  The dictionary 'attributes', or for NSAttributedString (Geometrics), the
00082  attributes of the receiver, must contain at least one key:
00083  NSFontAttributeName, with value an NSFont object.
00084  Other keys in 'attributes' are ignored.
00085  
00086  * DEGENERATE ARGUMENT CASES
00087  
00088  If the receiver has 0 -length, all of these methods will return 0.0.
00089  If 'font' argument is nil, will log error to console and return 0.0 x 0.0.
00090  
00091  It is sometimes useful to know that, according to Douglas Davidson,
00092  http://www.cocoabuilder.com/archive/message/cocoa/2002/2/13/66379,
00093  "The default font for text that has no font attribute set is 12-pt Helvetica."
00094  Can't find any official documentation on this, but it seems to be still
00095  true today, as of Mac OS 10.5.2, for NSTextView.  For NSTextField, however,
00096  the default font is 12-pt Lucida Grande.  
00097  
00098  If you pass a nil 'font' argument, these methods will log an error and
00099  return 0.0.  But if you pass an NSAttributedString with no font attribute
00100  for a run, these methods will calculate assuming 12-pt regular Helvetica.
00101 
00102  * INTERNAL DESIGN
00103  
00104  -[NSAttributedString sizeForWidth:height:] is the primitive workhorse method.
00105  All other methods in these @interfaces invoke this method under the hood.
00106  Basically, it stuffs your string into an NSTextContainer, stuffs this into
00107  an NSLayout Manager, and then gets the answer by invoking
00108  -[NSLayoutManager usedRectForTextContainer:].  The idea is copied from here:
00109  http://developer.apple.com/documentation/Cocoa/Conceptual/TextLayout/Tasks/StringHeight.html 
00110  
00111  * AUTHOR
00112  
00113  Please send bug reports or other comments to Jerry Krinock, jerry@ieee.org
00114  Updates may be available at http://sheepsystems.com/sourceCode
00115  
00116  * ACKNOWLEDGEMENTS
00117  
00118  Thanks very much to Steve Nygard for taking the project one night,
00119  recognizing the importance of the line fragment padding and hyphenation
00120  factor, and the idea of generalizing to support NSAttributedString.
00121  
00122  */
00123 
00124 #import <Cocoa/Cocoa.h>
00125 
00126 extern int gNSStringGeometricsTypesetterBehavior ;
00127 
00128 @interface NSAttributedString (Geometrics) 
00129 
00130 // Measuring Attributed Strings
00131 - (NSSize)sizeForWidth:(float)width 
00132                                 height:(float)height ;
00133 - (float)heightForWidth:(float)width ;
00134 - (float)widthForHeight:(float)height ;
00135 
00136 @end
00137 
00138 @interface NSString (Geometrics)
00139 
00140 // Measuring a String With Attributes
00141 - (NSSize)sizeForWidth:(float)width 
00142                                 height:(float)height
00143                         attributes:(NSDictionary*)attributes ;
00144 - (float)heightForWidth:(float)width
00145                          attributes:(NSDictionary*)attributes ;
00146 - (float)widthForHeight:(float)height
00147                          attributes:(NSDictionary*)attributes ;
00148 
00149 // Measuring a String with a constant Font
00150 - (NSSize)sizeForWidth:(float)width 
00151                                 height:(float)height
00152                                   font:(NSFont*)font ;
00153 - (float)heightForWidth:(float)width
00154                                    font:(NSFont*)font ;
00155 - (float)widthForHeight:(float)height
00156                                    font:(NSFont*)font ;
00157 
00158 @end
